description.narrative:
New/additional funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 This is an intervention for the continued support of MSEK 475 to the "UN Multi-Partnership Trust Fund" (MPTF) for Somalia in 2018-2019. In Decision 2016-002435, dated 30 June 2015, Sida decided to support MPTF 2015-2017 with an amount of 140 MSEK. Following the decision 52/16 from November 2016, an additional 33 MSEK was added and an additional 55 MSEK through decision 14/17, dated April 24, 2017 and finally 10 MSEK was added in Dwecember 2017 through decision 58/2017. Sida assess that the MPTF and the joint programs that Sweden contributes to delivers results despite some challenges that comes with implementation of programmes in a difficult context.
Somalia is one of the poorest countries in the world and is characterized by inequality. Recurrent humanitarian crises and armed conflicts pose challenging to the development of the country. Furthermore, Somalia is affected by climate change and recurring periods of drought. 2.3 million people have insecure food supplies and there are over one million internally displaced persons. Of a population of about 12 million, over 70% are poor and more than 40% live in extreme poverty. One of seven children dies before their first birthday; one of eighteen women die in childbirth; and only one in three persons have access to safe drinking water. Over 70% of Somalia's population is under thirty years and lack employment opportunities which leave many of them with few prospects for the future. Women are structurally discriminated and gender based violence is widespread. Somalia has the highest incidence of female genital mutilation in the world. Women also lack access to justice that can protect their interests. The lack of a formal and effective legal justice system in most parts of the country has led to extensive impunity. In 2017, Somalia was ranked as the most corrupt country in the world according to Transparency International.
However, a relatively peaceful political process for state building has begun. The increasing international support in recent years has contributed to progress in many areas. The implementation of the indirect parliamentary election held in the fall of 2016 with increased political representation of women in addition to the presidential elections in February 2017 followed by a peaceful change of power are particularly positive signs.
The MPTF was established in 2015 with Sweden as one of the first donors. The fund currently manages a total of USD 200 million. The two biggest donors are the EU followed by UK. So far, Sweden has contributed with 238 MSEK during the period and is thereby the third largest donor to the fund. During the period 2015-2017, Sweden has supported the central political processes (elections, constitution, parliament and the new federal state formation), the development of the judiciary, job creation for young people, and public administration. Furthermore, Sweden has provided support to the UN's core functions to enable effective implementation in a challenging context like Somalia. In addition, pilot support for the fund's so-called "national window", to use Somalia’s own country systems have been successfully supported to a prison rehabilitation facility, supplementing the above-mentioned legal aid program. Despite challenges on an overall level, it is Sida's assessment that these programs together deliver results.
Moreover, Sida assess that the MPTF is now fully established and that the programmes that are funded are implemented satisfactory. The international community has made significant commitments. Somalia has developed a National Development Plan (NDP) for Somalia 2017-2019. In addition, a Security Pact was adopted at the Somalia Conference held in May 2017 in London. The Security Pact sets out the roadmap for a Comprehensive Approach to Security, CAS. Hence, the UN has developed its own strategic plan (UNSF) for Somalia that reflects both the NDP and CAS. The MPTF is the main funding mechanism for UN support the implementation on the UNSF.
Sida assess that the MPTF continues to be relevant and appropriate mechanism to deliver support. Based on Sweden's development cooperation strategy for Somalia and the new Strategy to come, Sida proposes that the continued support to the MPTF shall be earmarked for the following thematic areas and for the programs decided in the framework of these: 1. Including policies, governance and federal state building, as well as reconciliation 2. Human rights, women, peace and security 3. Economic recovery and resilience 4. Reproductive, maternity and child health and rights
Within the area of Reproductive, maternity and child health and rights, 140 MSEK will be earmarked to UNFPA’s country programme for Somalia 2018-2020. For more information on the assessment of UNFPA as a strategic partner to Sida in Somalia, pleas se decision 28/2017, dated 2017-06-22. In addition, 60 MSEK shall be earmarked for the so-called "Enablers Program", which includes support for the UN Risk Management Unit, the UN department for Security, and the Resident Coordinator's Office (RCO), which is considered to be crucial for implementation of all development efforts in Somalia.
However, the MPTF is not only a financing mechanism but also constitutes a platform for donor coordination in a broader sense since it includes the major actors such as the EU, UK, US, NO, DE, and DK. At the same time, there is a trend that the EU and the UK are launching new bilateral programs in certain areas, while other donors such as DE will expand their support in favor of the MPTF. The MPTF is an important and a key instrument for cooperation between the international community and the Federal Government of Somalia to realize the overall development goals of sustainable peace and development in Somalia.
The MPTF will harmonize and align the significant resources that are channeled through the UN in Somalia and as such it is foreseen to a more effective international support for Somalia. If the international community, the FSG and other stakeholders cooperate to reduce the risks, it is Sida's assessment that objectives will be reached to a reasonable extent despite the complex context and the many challenges it entails.
The draft agreement follows that between the UNDP and Sida agreed template for the current form of cooperation. The new standard Standard Administrative Arrangement, SAA will regulate Sweden's contribution to the MPTF. The SAA will be signed by Sida and UNDP as the administrative agent. A Terms of Reference for the MPTF as well as a Memorandum of Understanding between all implementation UN partners are attached. Sida’s conditions in the contribution management rule are thereby fulfilled. Furthermore, a Memorandum of Agreement has been signed between the Government of Somalia and UNDP as an administrative agent.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen avser ett fortsatt stöd om 475 MSEK till "UN Multi-Partnership Trust Fund" (MPTF) för Somalia under 2018-2019. I beslut 2015-002435, daterat 30 juni 2015, fattade Sida beslut att stödja MPTF 2015-2017 med ett belopp på 140 MSEK. Ytterligare 33 MSEK tillsköts genom beslut 52/16 från November 2016 , samt ytterligare 55 MSEK genom beslut 14/17, från 24 april 2017 och slutligen 10 MSEK genom beslut 58/2017 från December 2017. Totalt har Sida utbetalt 238 MSEK under perioden 2015-2017. Sida gör bedömningen att MPTF och de program som Sverige bidrar till trots går tillfredsställande trots vissa utmaningar och levererar resultat i en svår miljö.
Somalia är ett av världens fattigaste länder och landet präglas av ojämställdhet och ojämlikhet. Återkommande humanitära kriser och väpnade konflikter utgör svåra utmaningar. Våld mot civilbefolkningen och grova brott mot mänskliga rättigheter är vanligt förekommande. Våldsam extremism utgör också en komplex utmaning för landet och den omgivande regionen. Problemet har också globala implikationer. Vidare påverkas Somalia av klimatförändringar och återkommande perioder av torka. 2,3 miljoner människor har osäker livsmedelsförsörjning och över en miljon är internflyktingar. Av en befolkning på ca 12 miljoner människor uppskattas drygt 70 % vara fattiga och drygt 40 % leva i extrem fattigdom. Ett av sju barn dör före sin första födelsedag; en av arton kvinnor dör under förlossning; och endast en av tre personer har tillgång till säkert dricksvatten. Över 70 % av Somalias befolkning är under trettio år och brist på sysselsättningsmöjligheter lämnar många av dem med få framtidsutsikter, vilket ytterligare bidrar till rekryteringsbasen för al Shabaab.
Kvinnor är strukturellt diskriminerade och könsrelaterat våld är utbrett. Somalia har den högsta förekomsten av kvinnlig könsstympning i världen. Kvinnor saknar dessutom tillgång till rättvisa som kan skydda deras rättigheter och tillvarata deras intressen. Bristen på ett formellt och effektivt rättssystem i de flesta delar av landet har lett till omfattande straffrihet. 2017 var Somalia rankat som det mest korrupta landet i världen enligt Transparency International.
Samtidigt har en relativt fredlig politisk process för återuppbyggnad av staten och dess institutioner inletts. Ett ökande internationellt stöd de senaste åren har bidragit till flera viktiga framsteg, exempelvis genomförandet av indirekta parlamentsval under hösten 2016, ökad politisk representation av kvinnor och presidentval i februari 2017 som ledde till ett fredligt maktskifte.
MPTF etablerades 2015 med Sverige som en av de första givarna. Fonden hanterar idag totalt 200 miljoner USD. De två största givarna är EU och UK. Det svenska bidraget på totalt 238 MSEK under perioden 2015-2017 perioden är det tredje största till fonden. Genom fonden har Sverige stött de centrala politiska processerna (val, konstitution, parlament och den nya federala statsbildningen), utvecklingen av rättsväsendet, jobbskapande för ungdomar, samt förvaltningsstöd. Vidare har Sverige lämnat stöd till FNs centrala funktioner som möjliggör närvaro, implementering och uppföljning i en svår och konfliktfylld kontext som Somalia. Dessutom har pilotstöd till fondens nationella fönster, där medel kanaliserades genom statsapparaten till en återuppbyggnad av ett fängelse i en av medlemsstaterna, vilket kompletter det ovan nämnda rättstödsprogrammet. Det är Sidas bedömning att dessa program sammantaget levererar resultat, trots stora utmaningar.
Sida gör även bedömningen att MPTF har etablerats fullt ut och fungerar tillfredställande, med ett betydande engagemang från bidragande givare, även om ett par givare börjar luta sig mot bilateral lösningar på vissa områden. Somalia har tagit fram en ny nationell utvecklingsplan 2017-2019 (National Development Plan - NDP). Därtill antog en säkerhetspakt vid den internationella Somalia-konferensen maj 2017 i London, vilken fastlägger färdplanen för genomförandet av en omfattande säkerhetsplan (Comprehensive Approach to Security, CAS) på federal och regional nivå. I ljuset av detta har FN tagit fram en strategisk plan (UNSF) som avspeglar NDP och CAS. MPTF är den främsta finansieringsmekanismen för FNs stöd till dess genomförande.
Sida bedömer att MPTF är ett fortsatt synnerligen relevant instrument som möjliggör ett flexibelt och ändamålsenlig stöd för att bidra till flera resultatområden i Sveriges strategi för utvecklingssamarbetet med Somalia. Sida föreslår att bidrag öronmärks kring följande tematiska områden och till de fondfinansierade FN program och projekt som beslutas inom ramen för dessa: 1. Inkluderande politik, samhällsstyrning och federal statsbyggnad, samt försoning 2. Mänskliga rättigheter, kvinnor, fred och säkerhet 3. Ekonomisk återuppbyggnad och motståndskraft 4. Reproduktiv-, mödra- och barnhälsa och rättigheter
Det finns två finansieringsfönster, ett FN-fönster där FN organisationer utgör implementerande part och ett nationellt fönster där Somalias regering genomför projekt i enlighet med ramverket för användandet av landets nationella system (use of country systems). UNDP är administrativ agent för hela fonden. Det svenska stödet kommer att gå till FN-fönstret av fonden, som sedan finansierar FN gemensamma projekt (UN Joint Programmes) som regleras genom Memorandum of Understanding mellan fonden och de implementerande FN organen. Medel utgår således från Sida, till UNDP som fondadministratör, och vidareförmedlas därefter till respektive ledande FN organ som ansvarar för programmets genomförande och uppföljning. Som fondadministratör, ansvarar UNDP för rapportering till givarna. Avstämningar sker i olika styrkomitteer på flera nivåer (givarsamordning tillsammans med Somalias regering samt på projektnivå) inom ramen för den etablerade samordningstrukturen (Somalia Development and Recontruction Facility- SDRF).
Inom området reproduktiv-, mödra- och barnhälsa och rättigheter kommer 140 MSEK öronmärkas till UNFPA:s landprogram för Somalia. (För fördjupad bedömning av UNFPA som strategisk parter i Somalia och av UNFPA:s landprogram 2018-2020, se beslut 28/2017, daterat 2017-06-22.)
Dessutom avses 60 MSEK öronmärkas till det så kallade "Enablers programme" som innefattar stöd till FNs riskhandteringsenhet, till avdelningen för säkerhet och trygghet, samt till Resident Coordinator's Office (RCO) vilket bedömds vara avgörande för alla utvecklingsinsatser i Somalia.
Avtalsutkastet följer den mellan UNDP och Sida överenskomna mallen för den nu gällande samarbetsformen. Det nya standardavtalet (Standard Administrative Arrangement, SAA) kommer att användas för att reglera Sveriges bidrag till fonden. Avtalet kommer att undertecknas av Sida och av UNDP som administrativ agent. En uppdragsbeskrivningen för MPTF samt ett Memorandum of Understanding mellan alla genomförandeparter är bilagda (utkast). Insatshanteringsregelns krav för avtal för SAA för FNs finansieringsfönster är uppfyllda. Vidare har ett Memorandum of Agreement ingåtts mellan FSG och UNDP som administrativ agent.
De juridiska förutsättningarna för att kunna lämna stöd även till det nationella fönstret diskuteras för närvrande mellan Sida/JUR och FN i New York. Om och när dessa diskusioner är avslutade kan ett eventuellt stöd till det nationella fönstret bli föremål för ett separat tilläggsbeslut.
MPTF harmoniserar betydande resurser som kanaliseras inom FN i Somalia och bidrar därmed till ett koordinerat internationellt stöd till Somalia. Trots många och allvarliga risker, är det Sidas bedömning att uppsatta mål kommer att nås till en rimlig grad om FN, deltagande givare och somaliska aktörer samarbetar för att minska dessa risker. Sverige och andra givare kommer att spela en viktig roll i detta avseende.
Det ska tilläggas att MPTF inte enbart utgör en finansieringsmekanism, utan fungerar även som en plattform för givarkoordinering i bredare bemärkelse och inbegriper de största givarna som EU, UK, USA, NO, DE, och DK. Fonden är därmed ett viktigt och centralt instrument för det internationella givarsamfundet och den somaliska regeringen i deras samarbete för att förverkliga de övergripande målen om fred och utveckling i Somalia. Samtidigt börjar EU och UK delvis initiera nya bilaterala program inom specifika områden, medan andra givare såsom DE kommer att utöka sitt stöd till MPTF.

Strengthening Women’s Capacities as Agents for Change in Peacebuilding, Reconciliation and Ending Violence Against Women Strengthening Women’s Capacities as Agents for Change in Peace-building, Reconciliation and Ending Violence Against Women programme is anchored on the recognition that gender equality is fundamental in achieving sustainable peace. The programme recognizes the imperative need to include women and girls in the political, legal, economic and social spheres to advance gender equality. It contributes to the National Development Plan (2017-2019) pillars on peace, inclusive politics, security and rule of law. The programme is further linked to the UN Strategic Framework (2017-2020) for Somalia and its Strategic Priority 1 (Deepening federalism and state-building, supporting conflict resolution and reconciliation, and preparing for universal elections) and Priority 2 (Supporting institutions to improve Peace, Security, Justice, the Rule of Law and safety of Somalis). The programme is being executed by UN Women as the lead UN entity in coordination with the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) through the Ministry of Women and Human Rights Development (MOWHRD). Key Objective The objective of this programme will be to create an enabling environment to promote participation and inclusion of women in decisions and efforts related to conflict prevention and resolution, women’s safety and security. The programme will also aim to contribute to the elimination of violence against women (EVAW), and to promote the socio-economic recovery of women. Expected Outcomes (i) Women’s leadership and participation in peacebuilding, conflict prevention and reconciliation is increased at community, federal and state levels. (ii) Positive coping mechanisms are promoted for marginalized women and girls at risk of involvement in violent extremism. (iii) Positive social norms, attitudes and behaviors are promoted at community and individual level to raise awareness on and prevent elimination of violence against women and girls.

tag.narrative: 10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.
10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
16.10 - Ensure public access to information and protect fundamental freedoms, in accordance with national legislation and international agreements.
16.10 - 0 Säkerställa allmän tillgång till information och skydda grundläggande friheter, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning och internationella avtal.
16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.
16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

description.narrative: This CoP presents the final assessment of the Joint Programme on Youth Employment Somalia (YES) which was implemented from September 2015 to December 2019. The activities of YES were implemented by 5 Participating United Nations Organizations (PUNOs) and these are: FAO, ILO, UNDP, UN-Habitat and UNIDO in collaboration with the Federal and local government authorities, local NGOs and the private sector. The lead ministry for the YES was the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (MoLSA).The donors supporting the program were Denmark, Italy, Sweden and Switzerland. The program was implemented in Mogadishu, Jubaland (Kismayo), Puntland (Bosaso), Somaliland (Hargeisa and Berbera), South West (Baidoa, Hudur) and Hirshabelle (Beletweyne). By the end of 2019, the youth employment program has created a total of 11686 short term and long-term youth jobs. Of these, 7236 were short-term Cash for Work (CFW) jobs and 4450 were long-term jobs from Skills Training and Value Chain interventions. The program reached a total of 12577 direct beneficiaries of which 7580 were male and 4998 were female. National ownership by the government was demonstrated by full involvement and cooperation of MOLSA and other government structures including development of a national employment strategy and finalization of the national labor force survey data sets including Somaliland. Within this activity period (Jan-Dec 2019), the key results reported are: 1. 1,334 unemployed young people received long-term employment, having set up 70 microenterprises or obtained jobs in construction, fishing, and renewable energy. 2. 863 youth received short-term employment opportunities through labour-intensive and apprenticeshipinitiatives. 3. In fish value chain development, 140 young fishers became self-employed and generating incomes for their households of around 1,000 members in Bossaso, Kismayo and Berbera. Having acquired technical and entrepreneurial skills as well as having access to 10 fish processing facilities, micro-grants and business development services, young fishers established 24 fishing cooperatives/micro-enterprises in Bossaso (12), Kismayo (6) and Berbera (6). 4. Additionally, 120 fishing families, with around 900 members, received 40 fiberglass reinforced fishing canoes, in Mogadishu, Bossaso, Berbera, Kismayo, Baidoa and Beletweyne. 5. Regional Hazard Analysis Critical Control Point (HACCP) guidelines on seafood safety and export were developed for Jubaland, Puntland and Somaliland. Over 150 representatives of the governments, fishery associations and businesses were oriented in the new regulations. 6. At least 30 at-risk youth became selfemployed having set up their own businesses in Hudur in South-West State while 75 at-risk youth improved their skills in market-oriented vocational trades and entrepreneurship having completed psycho-social counselling, literacy and numeracy sessions. 7. Seven hundred and ninety-six young people graduated from various training programmes, using a combination of skills training and on-the-job work experience to construct and rehabilitate various infrastructures in youth training centres and ministries in Kismayo, Baidoa, Dhobley, Beletweyne and Mogadishu. 8. An additional 384 youth improved their skills in solar panel installation and maintenance and entrepreneurship in Mogadishu, Baidoa and Kismayo. As a result, over 52 households and public facilities were provided electricity in the cities through the installation of solar panels. 9. The National Employment Policy (NEP) was developed and approved by the FGS Council of Ministers. A roadmap for the NEP implementation was developed which resulted in the development of a Somalia Employment Programme. The overall findings of the entire program are as follows: - The YES programme had a well-designed strategy that was both strategically aligned and relevant to the Somalia context and national development priorities. - According to the final evaluation, gender was fairly well mainstreamed within the programme. The programme reached a total of 12577 direct beneficiaries of which 7580 were male and 4998 were female. - The program had a strong national ownership by the government at federal and member state levels, which was demonstrated in the commitment and involvement of the government in program implementation. - The JPYES has left tangible program assets on the ground and this is commendable. The government demonstrated strong ownership of program assets by undertaking to maintain and sustain all the program assets – the roads and youth centres, training halls, etc. that were rehabilitated during the program life cycle. While there were positive findings from the programme, some challenges were also identified in the final evaluation. - The technical sustainability of the government was undermined by low capacity building effort and unclear roles for the different line ministries engaged in the programme. - The program design was based on a joint programming approach, but it was implemented on an individual basis, and it could not benefit from the efficiency benefits of synergy and collaboration of the joint approach. The roles of each PUNO were not clearly outlined, agreed upon and documented, including the targets and outcomes expectations. - The program lacked a strong PMU that could steer all the joint parties into focusing and achieving a common goal. It takes a robust and well-resourced PMU to accomplish a program’s vision and to achieve program targets. - Bureaucratic financial management processes during program implementation were also identified in contributiong to long delays in disbursing funds for timely program implementation, and this created time inefficiencies which prolonged program implementation.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
